tn.text: This word marks the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a word or phrase that does the same, you could use it here.
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:03:01|3:3]]. This is the a same as the "ark of the covenant of God" in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:04:03|4:3-4]].
This refers to the temple of Dagon, the god of the Philistines.
"they were very surprised to see that Dagon"

tn.ref: Dagon had fallen facedown on the ground
tn.text: The reader should understand that Yahweh had caused the statue to fall on its face during the night. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit|Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information]])
The reader should understand that Yahweh had caused Dagon to fall.

tn.ref: The head of Dagon and both of his hands were lying cut off
tn.text: It was as if Yahweh were a soldier who had defeated his enemy and cut off the enemy's head and hands.
The writer is about to give some background information separate from the main story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
Here "today" means up to the day when the author was writing this book.
This is an idiom. "Yahweh severely judged" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Possible meanings are 1) painful swelling under the skin or 2) hemorrhoids.
The name of the town is a metonym for the people living in the town. "both the people of Ashdod and the people in the land surrounding Ashdod" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"understood"

tn.ref: ark of the God of Israel
tn.text: Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:03:01|3:3]]. This is the a same as the "ark of the covenant of God" in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:04:03|4:3-4]].
This is an idiom. AT: "Yahweh punished" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Possible meanings are 1) this is a merism that refers to age. AT: "men of all ages" or 2) this is a merism that refers social class. AT: "from the poorest and weakest men to the richest and most powerful men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
Possible meanings are 1) painful swelling under the skin or 2) hemorrhoids. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:05:06|5:6]]
Why they cried out can be stated clearly. AT: "cried out in fear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the ark of God of Israel
tn.text: Translate this as you did the similar phrase [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:03:01|3:3]]. This is the a same as the "ark of the covenant of God" in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:04:03|4:3-4]].

Possible meanings are 1) they were speaking the proper name of the God of Israel or 2) they believed that Israel worshiped one of many gods, "the god of Israel." Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:05:06|5:7]].

tn.ref: there was a deathly panic throughout the city
tn.text: "people all over the city were afraid that they were going to die"

tn.ref: the hand of God was very heavy there
tn.text: The hand is a metonym for God punishing the people. "Yahweh was punishing the people there very severely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The men who did not die
tn.text: This implies that many men actually died. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Possible meanings are 1) painful swelling under the skin or 2) hemorrhoids. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:05:06|5:6]].

tn.ref: the cry of the city went up to the heavens
tn.text: The word "city" is a metonym for the people of the city. Possible meanings are 1) the words "went up to the heavens" is an idiom for "was very great." AT: "the people of the city cried out very loudly" or 2) the words "the heavens" is a metonym for the people's gods. AT: "the people of the city cried out to their gods." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
